reviewText: This game is notorious.\n\nFew puzzle games can be called hardcore
date:
and Chip's Challenge is one of them. Many puzzles in this game require trial-and-error. Many puzzles have random elements. Many puzzles are really long and take over ten minutes to finish. And there's no saving or rewinding -- one wrong move and you have to start the entire level over again, every time.

Oh, and there are time limits.

And the puzzles can be pretty hard, too. Hope you've been brushing up on your block-pushing.

If you've played a previous incarnation of Chip's Challenge before, you probably know what you're getting into. You'll find that this is a respectable remake, and you can even mod in the old graphics and sounds if you want. In addition, we've now got achievements, trading cards, and especially steam cloud syncing, which is very welcome.

If you haven't played this game before, well... just be warned that you're gonna need a lot of time and patience. Chip's Challenge is a test of character. The first time I played, it took me over five years just to get through half the levels.

But hey, that's just what it takes to get into the Bit Buster's club. They gotta keep out all of the lobotomy heads, you know.

As someone that grew up playing this game back on Windows 98, picking this up was a no-brainer. In all honesty, it's Chip's Challenge; how can you go wrong?

Still, it's worth a purchase; it's a classic.

reviewText:
If you've read my Chuck's Challenge 3D review, you'll know by now how much this game meant so much to me in my childhood. As such, I'll skip explaining it all over again and just quickly say a few things:

Chip's Challenge, released in 1989, is a puzzle game with Sokoban elements. I LOVED the complexity and variety in this game. I still do. The old feelings of frustration when you make a button press mistake when you're so close to finishing the level...as well as the old feelings of jubilation when you complete a fiendishly tricky level, are what, in my opinion, makes this game a stone cold classic and get a perfect rating of 10/10.

NOW: onto the remake itself.
This appears to feel mostly based on the Lynx version of the game (with moving animations and stuff) as opposed to the old MS version (where you have static moving images). It looks flashy and all but I grew up playing the MS version so I'm VERY used to those sprites. Thankfully, you can mod them (as well as the old songs) into the game and play it that way (check out the guides in the Community Hub).

Speaking of songs, while I initially planned to mod in the MS version music, I was pleasantly surprised and thrilled that the music was comprised of Scott Joplin piano rags. (They're public domain in case anyone's worried - i.e. perfectly free from copyright and can be used anywhere.) Ragtime has personally been one of my most favourite classical music genres, and while the renditions here are at times a bit too flat (ah well. You don't have a lot of room to put feeling into synthesized beats, I suppose.) and in the case of a few, a bit too fast, I find them still catchy and fun to listen to.

As far as I have observed, the old glitches and bugs from the MS version have been fixed, meaning some of the old exploits used to speedrun the game are no longer possible. This is part of the reasons where I feel the game loses some of its charm - the bugs were what used to make speedrunning more fun, and in some cases levels much less difficult and impossible. On the other side of the coin, some of the levels can now be played how they were originally intended to, which is a blessing I guess.

Definitely, for me the most negative aspects are the options menu and the sound effects. Selecting window size as 1x, 2x, 3x, 4x...not very helpful, in my opinion. Not just that but it also requires a program restart. I'd rather work with normal resolution option choices. I didn't quite like the new sound effects, and as another reviewer commented, they overpower the music when left on default settings. Of course, you can change the sound effect volumes, but I'd rather not have done that in the first place.

But still. This game gets a glowing recommendation from me, almost purely for the nostalgic value you'll get out of it if you've played the old one. Go forth and experience the joys and frustrations of my youth.

ALSO MOM I FINALLY BEAT BLOBNET AFTER 10+ YEARS, ARE YOU PROUD OF ME? :D

When to buy: You pick the price, I don't care. Anything goes, even full price. I recommend getting the bundle though, you get the long-awaited Chip's Challenge 2 and level editor. Quite a sweet deal.

10/10 (the game as a whole)
8.5/10 (this remake)

reviewText:
Okay, it may not seem like I've played this game much judging by my playtime on Steam. However, this is not the case. Far from the case. I've sank so many hours into the Microsoft Best of Entertainment Pack version it's not even funny. I have fond memories playing this game as a child. The pain. The suffering. The heavenly reward of touching the blue glowy wormhole at the end.

Over the years, I've beaten the game numerous times. Meaning about twice. There's hundreds of levels in the game, ranging from extremely simple, to fairly challenging, to stupidly simple and mundane, to 'Jesuschristijustwanttofinishthis♥♥♥♥♥♥♥levelfor♥♥♥♥ssakeimgonnakillsomebody'.

Yeah. Good thing is, the difficulty is paced fairly evenly. The level layouts are genius, the puzzles are world-class. The controls are nice and simple, and the looks nice.

This brings me to this port.

The Steam port isn't actually that bad. The real only changes is that the sprites are more of a cross between the original Atari Lynx and the Windows version, which isn't a bad thing. For instance, Chip is actually animated, and the screen scrolls properly, unlike the Windows version, which is more of a jittery mess. I like it. It's easy enough to adjust to.

However, the music is a different story. The Lynx version had awesome chiptunes, the Windows had the most nostalgic midis, and this has...'eh'-best piano tracks. They don't exactly fit as well as the others, but it's really nothing special to write home about otherwise. If it's really bothersome, just mute it and throw on whatever you want in the background since the game runs in windowed mode.

On that, there is a serious issue with the game. It is windowed. Normally this isn't much of an issue with games like this, but it's unscaleable. The default ratio is what you get. For me, I don't have that large of a monitor, and the game is big enough, but for those with larger monitors, such as 4k, this will be a big problem. Hopefully this'll be patched soon. Along with workship support. Seriously, a tilepack to make it look just like the windows version would be godly.

Overall, hell yes get this game. It seems most of the negative reviews are either from people having the display problem or just nostalgiatards who can't stand the difference from the Windows version. Get over it. Enjoy the freaking game. It was $1.99 which is a steal considering you can't even get the original games outside of the Lynx and DOS ports. Oh hey, there's a sequel out now, too. I hope it's good considering the near 20-something-year wait...

reviewText:
Chip's Challenge is a tale of the indomitable spirit that burns in the hearts of men. The long road stretches before all of us, obscured by great oceans, blazing wildfires, frozen wastelands, and one-way directional floor tiles. Our dreams are hidden behind closed doors, and only the most courageous among us seek out the appropriately-colored keys. Chip is one such courageous individual. He will not rest until his demons are conquered and the challenges set before him lie as blazing piles of ash in his wake.

He endures the pain and the sorrow, he fights through tears and blood, and he hits reset for the one-hundredth time after pushing a block into the wrong water tile. He does this for love, for the hand of Melinda the Mental Marvel, but he also does this for himself. In conquering the insects, the rocket ships, and the chattering teeth, in walking across the fires, sacrificing the technological relics, and traversing the transdimensional portals, he ascends beyond his own mortal shortcomings and into the realm of gods. His chains unfettered, he is unstoppable. He is the hunter, and block puzzles are his prey.

This is not merely a game. This is a rite of passage into your own potential. This is the mountain that stands in your way, the path you must build with your own two hands. This is your Andre the Giant. This is your King George III. This is your Apollo Creed. When the chips are down and it's your call, are you all talk or do you have something to show? Does the blood of the warriors pulse in your veins? Are you one star shining in the night sky brighter than all the other stars?

Just who the hell do you think you are?

It feels like coming home.\n\nI miss Chip's original look and the green circuit board background but otherwise the updated graphics look great and the game feels pretty much the same. There's two movement options you can toggle between, one for smoothly moving on to tiles and another for snapping on to them like the original. Some of the puzzles can be tedious but it's great to play it again after so long and the nostalgia is strong with this one.

For those of you who either weren't born yet or lived under a rock during the 90's, this delightful puzzle game will both entertain & infuriate you, but you'll likely enjoy every tendonitis-inducing minute of it. As for those of us who grew up navigating the many levels of Melinda The Mental Marvel's clubhouse, this particular edition of the beloved game will bring back all of those nostalgia-feels we've been craving since the turn of the century. A highly recommended addition to any puzzle-player's gaming library.

I adore both the Windows Entertainment Pack and Atari LYNX versions of Chip's Challenge, but this one has some major problems.

MUSIC & SOUND

GRAPHICS & ANIMATION
Ugly ugly ugly. The sprites look miserably out of place with tiles and backgrounds. The time it takes to get from tile to tile seems a little long/slippery. The frames of animation are oddly smooth for what is taking place. Think PopCap games.

And without those two features

reviewText:
Let's take one of the greatest classics in computer gaming history and ruin it.

The revamped graphics, music, and sound effects are just plain awful. The originals were so much better.

You would think that the now-'smoothed' movement would make the gameplay more seamless, but in fact it makes it unncessarily tedious and more error prone. In the original, movements were fairly discrete, so there was no ambiguity with regards to timing of movements. Whereas in the original I could hold down the arrow keys without too much fear of overstepping, in this version I find myself tapping the keys because of how aggressive the game handles movement. The lack of an undo feature means that you could easily waste half an hour on a puzzle that otherwise takes 3 minutes to solve, simply because you accidentally held a key for two long, or accidentally tapped the wrong key. (No, I do not believe the level skip feature makes up for this inexcusable omission.)

The game is intended to be a puzzle game, not an action game; I should not have to micromanage my movements in relation to enemies apart from general high-level strategy!

I loved the original, but this remake is so very disappointing. As far as I've concerned, I've paid for the game, so I feel entitled to download a bootleg of the original and play that one instead of this ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ized version.

Must. Beat. Level.\n\nEasily one of my favourite games of my childhood, up there with Pokemon Yellow, Ocarina of Time and Worms: Armageddon. A classic from the Microsoft Entertainment Pack, you'll find this skill-based puzzle game too addictive to not play. Unfortunately, some of the later levels take longer to finish, but otherwise you can simply play one or two levels in a sitting and be satisfied (or enraged).

If you like puzzles, you'll love this game.

Chip's Challenge is the same straight-forward yet entirely maddening puzzle game you remember from the Best of Entertainment pack on Windows 95. This version looks slightly different from that, and the movement is a little bit different as well but not frustratingly so. You adapt very quickly.

I haven't gotten far enough to see if the bonus levels are included in this one or not, but it's everything my mother, brother and I loved about CC when I was a kid, but now in a package that doesn't require an emulator set up to play.

What I really love about CC is that you can sit down and work on a puzzle for a whole afternoon, or you can try a few times and keep coming back to it until you get it figured out, and then come back to it a few more times until you're able to execute the solution without burning, drowning, sliding, forcing, monstering or time-outing into oblivion.

You may find graph paper and coloured pencils helpful, although there are also an abundance of level maps and walkthroughs available online if you're not the sort to draw out your own solutions.

The one downfall CC has is that most of the puzzles, once solved, do not have a ton of replay value; however the sheer number of levels in the game does IMO make up for this shortcoming.

9.5/10
